title: Race Against The Machine: How the Digital Revolution is Accelerating Innovation, Driving Productivity, and Irreversibly Transforming Employment and the Economy
author: Erik Brynjolfsson
summary: "In Race Against the Machine Brynjolfsson and McAfee bring together a range of statistics, examples, and arguments to show that the average worker is not keeping up with cutting-edge technologies, and so is losing the race against the machine. The book makes the case that employment prospects are grim for many today not because there’s been technology has stagnated, but instead because we humans and our organizations aren’t keeping up."

title: The Singularity Is Near: When Humans Transcend Biology
author: Ray Kurzweil
summary: "[Kurzweil] examines the next step in this inexorable evolutionary process: the union of human and machine, in which the knowledge and skills embedded in our brains will be combined with the vastly greater capacity, speed, and knowledge-sharing ability of our creations."
reviews: "The basis for the foundation of (Diamandis's school) Singularity University."

title: Creation: How Science is Reinventing Life Itself
author: Adam Rutherford
summary: "As we come closer and closer to understanding the ancient root that connects all living things, Adam Rutherford shows how we may finally be able to achieve the creation of new life where none existed before."

title: Debt: The First 5,000 Years
author: David Graeber
summary: "Here anthropologist David Graeber presents a stunning reversal of conventional wisdom: he shows that before there was money, there was debt."
reviews: "The gripping saga of how debt — an abstract virus — became the default operating system for all human commerce."

"His theory about where did money come from is mind-blowing [...] It turns out there's no evidence of [the traditional theory of where money comes from]. Instead, [Dave] argues that money was invented to keep track of debt, and that debt predates money."

title: Little Brother
author: Cory Doctorow
summary: "Marcus, a.k.a 'w1n5t0n,' is only seventeen years old, but he figures he already knows how the system works–and how to work the system. Smart, fast, and wise to the ways of the networked world, he has no trouble outwitting his high school's intrusive but clumsy surveillance systems."
reviews: "It's a great story about teenagers, net culture, security, activism and politics and was a lot of fun to read. It references a lot of real-life stuff like XBox hacks and ARGs and is classic Cory."
"If you're into security and privacy."

title: Models.Behaving.Badly: Why Confusing Illusion with Reality Can Lead to Disaster, on Wall Street and in Life
author: Emanuel Derman
summary: "Quants, physicists working on Wall Street as quantitative analysts, have been widely blamed for triggering financial crises with their complex mathematical models. Their formulas were meant to allow Wall Street to prosper without risk. But in this penetrating insider’s look at the recent economic collapse, Emanuel Derman—former head quant at Goldman Sachs—explains the collision between mathematical modeling and economics and what makes financial models so dangerous."
reviews: "[Derman] convincingly establishes the difference between model and theory and shows why attempts to model financial markets can never be genuinely scientific. It vindicates those of us who hold that financial modeling is neither practical nor scientific. Exceedingly readable."

title: You Are Not a Gadget: A Manifesto
author: Jaron Lanier
summary: "A programmer, musician, and father of virtual reality technology, Jaron Lanier was a pioneer in digital media, and among the first to predict the revolutionary changes it would bring to our commerce and culture. Now, with the Web influencing virtually every aspect of our lives, he offers this provocative critique of how digital design is shaping society, for better and for worse."

title: Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion
author: Bob Cialdini
summary: "Influence, the classic book on persuasion, explains the psychology of why people say 'yes'—and how to apply these understandings. Dr. Robert Cialdini is the seminal expert in the rapidly expanding field of influence and persuasion."
reviews: "Every sales and marketing person needs to read it."

title: The Innovator's Dilemma: The Revolutionary Book That Will Change the Way You Do Business
author: Clayton Christensen
summary: "The Innovator’s Dilemma is the revolutionary business book that has forever changed corporate America. Based on a truly radical idea—that great companies can fail precisely because they do everything right—this Wall Street Journal, Business Week and New York Times Business bestseller is one of the most provocative and important business books ever written."
reviews: "This was a formative read for me: it taught me why it’s so hard to come up with a second hit and why startups often have the advantage when creating curve-jumping innovation."

"An analysis of why great companies fail, because innovation often requires throwing out everything that has made you successful in the past. Disruptive technologies are often born on the fringes, in markets where worse is better."

title: The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Fail
author: Nate Silver
summary: "Drawing on his own groundbreaking work, Silver examines the world of prediction, investigating how we can distinguish a true signal from a universe of noisy data. Most predictions fail, often at great cost to society, because most of us have a poor understanding of probability and uncertainty."

title: Automate This: How Algorithms Came to Rule Our World
author: Christopher Steiner
summary: "Christopher Steiner tells the story of how algorithms took over—and shows why the 'bot revolution' is about to spill into every aspect of our lives, often silently, without our knowledge."

title: Creating Innovators: The Making of Young People Who Will Change the World
author: Tony Wagner
summary: "From a prominent educator, author, and founder of Harvard’s Change Leadership Group comes a provocative look at why innovation is today’s most essential real-world skill and what young people need from parents, teachers, and employers to become the innovators of America’s future."

title: The Effective Executive: The Definitive Guide to Getting the Right Things Done
author: Peter Drucker
summary: "Ranging widely through the annals of business and government, Peter F. Drucker demonstrates the distinctive skill of the executive and offers fresh insights into old and seemingly obvious business situations."
reviews: "I devoured this book while in college. I can’t say that I’ve always been an effective executive, but Peter Drucker was a hero of mine."

title: The Filter Bubble: How the New Personalized Web Is Changing What We Read and How We Think
author: Eli Pariser
summary: "The Filter Bubble tells the story of how the Internet, a medium built around the open flow of ideas, is closing in on itself under the pressure of commerce and 'monetization.'"

title: The Gamification Revolution: How Leaders Leverage Game Mechanics to Crush the Competition
author: Gabe Zichermann
summary: "Gamification uses the latest innovations from game design, loyalty programs, and behavioral economics to help you cut through the noise and transform your organization into a lean, mean machine ready to fight the battle for user attention and loyalty."

title: If You Want to Write: A Book about Art, Independence and Spirit
author: Brenda Ueland
summary: "For most, the hardest part of writing is overcoming the mountain of self-denial that weighs upon the spirit, always threatening to extinguish those first small embers of ambition. Brenda Ueland, a writer and teacher, devotes most of her book--published back in 1938, before everyone and their goldfish got their MFA's in creative writing--to these matters of the writer's heart."
reviews: "Perhaps my favorite book of all time. It was my guiding light when I first started writing. Obviously, the book is for writers, but if you substitute 'program,' 'market,' 'evangelize,' or 'start' for the word 'write,' you’ll see why its concepts are widely applicable.

title: Loyalty 3.0: How Big Data and Gamification are Revolutionizing Customer and Employee Engagement
author: Rajat Paharia
summary: "Paharia shows you how to create a system powered by human motivation and digital technology that creates ongoing, persistent engagement among customers, employees, and partners."

title: Mastering the Dynamics of Innovation
author: James Utterback
summary: "The author presents a compelling look at how innovation transforms industries, raising the fortunes of some firms while destroying others."
reviews: "This book opened my eyes with evidence and findings about innovation."

title: The Pema Chodron Audio Collection: Pure Meditation:Good Medicine:From Fear to Fearlessness
author: Pema Chodron
summary: "Pema Chodron, one of the West's most beloved teachers of Buddhism, makes the Tibetan vajrayana tradition accessible in today's world."
reviews: "She is a Buddhist nun who has a monastery in Nova Scotia [...] We are falling, falling, with nothing to hold on to and nothing to slow us down. The good news is there is no ground to land on."

title: To Save Everything, Click Here: The Folly of Technological Solutionism
author: Evgeny Morozov
summary: "Arguing that we badly need a new, post-Internet way to debate the moral consequences of digital technologies, To Save Everything, Click Here warns against a world of seamless efficiency, where everyone is forced to wear Silicon Valley’s digital straitjacket."

title: The Startup of You: Adapt to the Future, Invest in Yourself and Transform Your Career
author: Reid Hoffman
summary: "The career escalator is jammed at every level. Unemployment rates are sky-high. Creative disruption is shaking every industry. Global competition for jobs is fierce. The employer-employee pact is over and traditional job security is a thing of the past."

title: Taming The Big Data Tidal Wave: Finding Opportunities in Huge Data Streams with Advanced Analytics
author: Bill Franks
summary: "Taming the Big Data Tidal Wave isn’t just the title of this book, but rather an activity that will determine which businesses win and which lose in the next decade. By preparing and taking the initiative, organizations can ride the big data tidal wave to success rather than being pummeled underneath the crushing surf."

title: The Tom Peters Seminar: Crazy Times Call For Crazy Organizations
author: Tom Peters
summary: "The Tom Peters Seminar demonstrates Peters' unconventional analysis that challenges outdated corporate structures and demonstrates that in the 1990s, 'imagination is the source of value in the economy.'"
reviews: "Short, illustrated, fun, breezy, and powerful. Overlooked, it's his most accessible work, which says a lot."

title: Addiction by Design: Machine Gambling in Las Vegas
author: Natasha Dow Schull
summary: "Addiction by Design takes readers into the intriguing world of machine gambling, an increasingly popular and absorbing form of play that blurs the line between human and machine, compulsion and control, risk and reward."

title: Antifragile: Things That Gain from Disorder
author: Nassim Taleb

title: The Art of Possibility: Transforming Professional and Personal Life
author: Rosamund Stone Zander
reviews: "The two of them will completely change the way you think about possibility, about enrollment, about leadership. I listen it about once a month in the car [audio version]."

title: Better, Stronger, Faster: The Myth of American Decline . . . and the Rise of a New Economy
author: Daniel Gross

title: Big Data: A Revolution That Will Transform How We Live, Work, and Think
author: Viktor Mayer-Schonberger

title: The Chicago Manual of Style
author: University of Chicago
reviews: "This is the definitive book on how to handle the tweaky issues that come up in writing."

title: The Circle
author: Dave Eggers

title: Conscious Capitalism: Liberating the Heroic Spirit of Business
author: John Mackey

title: Crossing the Chasm: Marketing and Selling High-Tech Products to Mainstream Customers
author: Geoffrey Moore
reviews: "I learned the hard way about chasms while working for Apple. The early adopters are easy–'main street' is hard. Entrepreneurs should read this book when they are cranking out their “conservative” sales projections."

title: Cyber War: The Next Threat to National Security and What to Do About It
author: Richard A. Clarke

title: The Diamond Age: Or, a Young Lady's Illustrated Primer
author: Neal Stephenson
reviews: "[It changes your mind] before you've thought about molecular anything or 3d printing .. he wrote this book before the iPad or the Kindle."

title: The Hockey Handbook: The Classic Teaching Guide
author: Lloyd Percival
reviews: "Probably the best book ever written about hockey tactics–although this opinion is coming from a Hawaiian who took up hockey at forty-eight, so you never know"

title: Inevitable Illusions: How Mistakes of Reason Rule Our Minds
author: Massimo Piattelli-Palmarini
reviews: "This book should have been called, How Entrepreneurs Think because it explains how entrepreneurs confuse themselves. I salute the people who can read this book and not find a mistake of reasoning that they’ve made."

title: Just Kids
author: Patti Smith
reviews: "It's about love, loss, and art. It's about non-confidence and confidence and about having a best friend."

title: Makers: The New Industrial Revolution
author: Chris Anderson
reviews: "If you're into 3D printing."

title: New Rules for the New Economy
author: Kevin Kelly
reviews: "An essential book when Kevin Kelly published it more than a decade ago, and even more essential now. Ignore its lessons at your peril."

title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
author: Daniel Kahneman
summary: "Daniel Kahneman, the renowned psychologist and winner of the Nobel Prize in Economics, takes us on a groundbreaking tour of the mind and explains the two systems that drive the way we think. System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional; System 2 is slower, more deliberative, and more logical."
reviews: "Most 'idea books' are bloated essays; this one, from a Nobel Prize–winning economist, is worth reading all the way through. Kahneman offers a fascinating set of ideas about how human beings think and reason, for better and worse.

title: Snow Crash
author: Neal Stephenson
summary: "Only once in a great while does a writer come along who defies comparison-- a writer so original he redefines the way we look at  the world. Neal Stephenson is such a writer and Snow Crash is such a novel, weaving  virtual reality, Sumerian myth, and just about everything in between with a cool, hip  cyber-sensibility to bring us the gigantic thriller of the  information age."
reviews: "It's such a great book, like, you can't give it to someone now, I've tried. You'd have to have given it to someone before you've been on the Internet. Then it changes your mind."

title: Uncommon Genius: How Great Ideas are Born
author: Denise Shekerjian
summary: "Drawing on interviews with 40 winners of the MacArthur Foundation Fellowship—the so-called 'genius awards'—the insightful study throws fresh light on the creative process."
reviews: "A lovely book that gets into the minds of the 'genius' award winners of the MacArthur Foundation. There’s a lot to learn about ”mastery“ from these award winners and much of it can be applied to business."

title: Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art
author: Scott McCloud
summary: "Praised throughout the cartoon industry by such luminaries as Art Spiegelman, Matt Groening, and Will Eisner, this innovative comic book provides a detailed look at the history, meaning, and art of comics and cartooning."
reviews: "As Scott McCloud has pointed out [...], all the action in comics happens in between the panels [...] In Panel A something happened and in Panel B something happened, but it's what happened between A and B that changed your mind about anything."

title: The War of Art
author: Steve Pressfield
summary: "Since 2002, The War of Art has inspired people around the world to defeat Resistance; to recognize and knock down dream-blocking barriers and to silence the naysayers within us."
reviews: "This is Steve Pressfield's classic book about the Resistance and the cost of fighting it (or ignoring it). We don't need more me too from you."

title: What You Can Change and What You Can't: The Complete Guide to Successful Self-Improvement
author: Martin Seligman
summary: "Martin Seligman has meticulously analyzed the most authoritative scientific research on treatments for alcoholism, anxiety, weight loss, anger, depression, and a range of phobias and obsessions to discover what is the most effective way to address each condition. He frankly reports what does not work, and pinpoints the techniques and therapies that work best for each condition, discussing why they work and how you can use them to make long lasting change."

title: Zig Ziglar’s Secrets of Closing the Sale
author: Zig Ziglar
summary: "This new guide by America's #1 professional in the art of persuasion focuses on the most essential part of the sale—how to make them say 'Yes, I will!'"
reviews: "Zig Ziglar's classic book. It seems like it's filled with lessons from a door-to-door salesman, but the secrets go far deeper than that. It's about commitment and vulnerability and telling the truth."
